Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Managing Ecological and Cultural Value on Rural Lands

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Rural land management has always been an important topic in the United States as the Federal Government and other landowners have sought to balance economic value of rural lands and resources with the preservation of our natural and cultural heritage. These issues have only grown more significant and complex because of conflicting understandings about the environmental and heritage value of rural lands as well as increased participation of non-profits and the public in land management practices. This project, which trains a student in the methods of empirical, scientific data collection and analysis, asks how land managers balance these myriad priorities to improve processes of public involvement in land management planning. In addition to providing funding for the training of a graduate student in anthropology, the project would enhance scientific understanding by broadly disseminating its findings to organizations invested in discovering more effective means of navigating land management, improving policies and practices, and promoting environmental, cultural, and economic sustainability.

Doctoral student Julia Sizek, supervised by Dr. Daniel Fisher at the University of California-Berkeley, will explore what factors influence shifts in land management policies and practices on rural lands. Research conducted in Southeastern California's Mojave Desert, an area gaining increasing visibility as both a place of ecological value and a site of Native American, homesteading, and military history. This region is currently in the process of land management planning for two new national monuments (Mojave Trails National Monument and Castle Mountains National Monuments, established 2016), but also contains a contentious National Park Service unit: the Mojave National Preserve, established in 1994. By studying how members of environmental and Native American organizations participate in land management planning and understand the value of the desert, this research will reveal the cultural and ecological value of desert lands as understood today, and how this affects land management priorities. This research will also follow land managers on privately and publicly-held conservation lands, seeing how land management practices (e.g. use regulations, fence-building, trail-building, reseeding, signage) are changing in the desert as understandings of desert ecology and the extent of historical and cultural research are becoming more accurate. Data about understandings of the desert and scientific advances will be collected through interviews with relevant experts, analysis of environmental events aimed at public participation in planning processes, and site visits to areas of ecological restoration and desert protection. The project will advance theoretical debates about land and governance under conditions of environmental uncertainty, and the effects of heterogeneity in land conservation practices. Research results will be relevant to landscape-scale environmental planning processes happening in the Mojave Desert and elsewhere, and will also show how perceptions of the environmental value of the desert are shifting and with what effects for land management.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The major goals of this research were to understand the factors that influence shifts in land management policies and practices on rural lands in the United States, focusing on the eastern Mojave Desert in Southeastern California. The California desert region is particularly interesting because Euroamerican settlers understood the area as a wasteland and transit area rather than a place of habitation, eliding the deep histories of Chemehuevi, Mojave, and Serrano peoples in the region. The desert was both a military and dirt bike recreational playground available for mining and other extractive uses throughout the early part of the twentieth century. Economic values triumphed over cultural and ecological ones until the 1976 passage of the Federal Land and Policy Management Act (FLPMA) that mandated the creation of a management plan for the vast 25 million acres, of California desert, which covers a quarter of the state. FLPMA and the later California Desert Protection Act of 1994 corresponded to a generalized increased interest in the beauty and wonder of the California desert, as well as increased presence of land trusts, non-profit conservation entities whose growth began under 1980s neoliberal reforms. While many land trusts sought to protect land for ecological conservation, an intertribal land trust, the Native American Land Conservancy, formed in 1998 to protect sacred sites. Today, both state-led management changes—through policies like the Desert Renewable Energy Conservation Plan and the establishment of new National Monuments in the region—as well as privately-led changes—like a proposal for a groundwater extraction project. Importantly, though, almost all projects depend on land use planning processes regulated under both federal and local laws, a point made clear during conducting field research.

 

During the funding period, the Co-PI spent six months of archival research at local historical societies, participant-observation with both indigenous and non-indigenous conservation professionals and volunteers, and interviews with locals not affiliated with conservation entities. The Co-PI hiked, camped, restored damaged lands, picked up trash, attended meetings, and filed paperwork with employees of land trusts in order to understand how land management is changing today and contending with environmental uncertainty.

 

The NSF-funded portions of this research focused on contemporary land use conflict in two main arenas: the effects of pollution and dumping in the California desert, and the legal regimes that intersect railroad land grants and California Indian lands. For the former, the Co-PI used both contemporary activism around pollution as well as archival research in local historical societies and at the National Archives in Riverside to examine how contemporary understandings of pollution and dumping were linked both to the twentieth century understanding of the desert as wasteland as it was to dominant wind patterns that linked the history of Los Angeles and its famous smog to the California desert. For the latter, the Co-PI examined sales of railroad land grants as well as the history of the Chemehuevi, Twentynine Palms Band of Mission Indians, and Agua Caliente Band of Cahuilla Indians reservations, drawing on both interviews with Native American tribal members and non-indigenous activists, archival research, and contemporary legal filings for projects. Finally, the researcher spent the time attending yearly environmental events, land monitoring, and restoration activities with land trust employees and volunteers. These two areas of research reveal the common themes of the dissertation: how understandings of state and public property shape contemporary regimes of land management, as do the intersection of country-city dynamics and historical influences.

 

The Co-PI’s dissertation, to be completed in 2021, will make important contributions to anthropology and geography by bringing together debates in legal anthropology/geography, economic anthropology/geography, political ecology, and Native American and Indigenous Studies. This research will also contribute to contemporary debates about land management among federal officials, offering insights for more effective administration of the checkerboard of private and public lands. This research has also already resulted in public-facing publications and presentations and collaborations with underrepresented minorities (Native American tribes).
